samples.single-turn question: What notices must a state member bank provide to the Federal Reserve and branch customers before closing a seasonal branch?
multi-turn questions: What are the current regulatory requirements for state member banks when considering branch closures?
What notices must a state member bank provide to the Federal Reserve and branch customers before closing a seasonal branch?
samples.answer: A "seasonal branch" is a branch that is operated by a state member bank for multiple limited periods of time to provide branch banking services (i) at a specified recurring event, (ii) on the grounds or premises where the event is held or at a fixed site adjacent to the grounds or premises where the event is held, and (iii) exclusively during the occurrence of the event. Examples of a seasonal branch include the operation of a branch during school registration periods on the campus of a college or at a fixed site adjacent to the campus, and the operation of a branch during a state fair on state fairgrounds or at a fixed site adjacent to the fairgrounds. Seasonal branches are not considered temporary branches, and the branch closure notice requirements under section 42 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act apply to the closure of seasonal branches. Section 42 requires a state member bank that proposes to close any branch to provide notice of the proposed closing to the Federal Reserve at least 90 days prior to closing, to mail notice to affected customers informing them of the planned closing at least 90 days prior to closing, and to post a notice at the branch site at least 30 days prior to closing. Seasonal branches, however, are often open for less than 30 consecutive days at a time. In these cases, Board staff has considered the 30-day notice posting requirement to be fulfilled where notice of the planned closure is posted at the seasonal branch for the entire duration that the branch is open, even if the branch is open for less than 30 days. The notice posting requirement may also be fulfilled by posting notice for the full 30 days at the site of the recurring event at any time prior to closure of the seasonal branch, even if the event is not occurring during that 30-day period. The seasonal branch would then be deemed closed once all notice requirements, including the 90-day notice to the Federal Reserve and the 90-day notice to customers, are fulfilled.

Examples of seasonal branches include operations during school registration periods on a college campus or at a fixed site adjacent to the campus
Examples of seasonal branches also include operations during a state fair on state fairgrounds or at a fixed site adjacent to the fairgrounds
Seasonal branches are not considered temporary branches
Section 42 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act applies to the closure of seasonal branches
A state member bank must provide notice of the proposed closing to the Federal Reserve at least 90 days prior to closing a seasonal branch
A state member bank must mail notice to affected customers informing them of the planned closing at least 90 days prior to closing a seasonal branch
A state member bank must post a notice at the branch site at least 30 days prior to closing a seasonal branch
In cases where a seasonal branch is open for less than 30 consecutive days, the 30-day notice posting requirement is fulfilled by posting notice for the entire duration the branch is open

The 30-day notice posting requirement can also be fulfilled by posting notice for the full 30 days at the site of the recurring event at any time prior to closure, even if the event is not occurring during that period
A seasonal branch is deemed closed once all notice requirements, including the 90-day notice to the Federal Reserve and the 90-day notice to customers, are fulfilled.

samples.single-turn question: What constitutes a change in the general character of a state member bank's business for purposes of section 208.3(d)(2) of Regulation H?
multi-turn questions: Can you explain what activities are typically considered normal for a state member bank under Regulation H?
What constitutes a change in the general character of a state member bank's business for purposes of section 208.3(d)(2) of Regulation H?
samples.answer: Under Regulation H, a member bank must "at all times conduct its business and exercise its powers with due regard to safety and soundness" and "may not, without the permission of the Board, cause or permit any change in the general character of its business or in the scope of the corporate powers it exercises at the time of admission to membership." Changes in the general character of a bank's business are those that fundamentally or materially change a bank's core business plan. Such changes may present novel risks for the bank, depending on how they are conducted and managed, and may present risks to the deposit insurance fund. In addition, such changes may involve aggressive growth plans that may give rise to significant financial, managerial, and other supervisory issues.

Without the permission of the Board, a member bank may not cause or permit any change in the scope of the corporate powers it exercises at the time of admission to membership
Changes in the general character of a bank's business are ones that fundamentally or materially change a bank's core business plan
Such changes may present novel risks for the bank, depending on how they are conducted and managed
Such changes may present risks to the deposit insurance fund
Such changes may involve aggressive growth plans that may give rise to significant financial issues
Such changes may involve aggressive growth plans that may give rise to significant managerial issues

samples.single-turn question: What requirements must be satisfied before a state member bank may declare and pay a dividend of property other than cash?
multi-turn questions: What rules and conditions must state member banks follow when distributing dividends?
What requirements must be satisfied before a state member bank may declare and pay a dividend of property other than cash?
samples.answer: Pursuant to section 9(6) of the Federal Reserve Act, a state member bank must obtain the prior approval of the Board before it may declare a dividend of property other than cash. 12 U.S.C. § 324. The Board has delegated to the Federal Reserve Banks the authority to approve a request by a state member bank to declare a dividend of property other than cash if the request does not raise significant legal, supervisory, or policy issues.

samples.single-turn question: What kinds of banking facilities are not considered "branches" for purposes of section 42 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act (12 U.S.C. § 1831r-1), and thus do not require agency notice if they are closed?
multi-turn questions: How have banking regulations and classifications for different types of banking facilities evolved over time?
What is the current regulatory landscape regarding the classification of various banking offices under FDIC regulations?

What kinds of banking facilities are not considered "branches" for purposes of section 42 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act (12 U.S.C. § 1831r-1), and thus do not require agency notice if they are closed?
samples.answer: Section 42 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act requires that insured depository institutions follow a notice process for branch closings. A 1999 joint policy statement on branch closings issued by the federal banking agencies clarified that automated teller machines, remote service facilities, loan production offices, temporary branches, and insured branches of foreign banks are not branches for purposes of section 42 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. The policy statement also clarified that a bank's main office is not a branch for purposes of section 42.

A bank's main office is not considered a branch for purposes of section 42 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act
Insured depository institutions must follow a notice process for branch closings under section 42 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act

samples.single-turn question: Is a state member bank that relocates its main office required to file a branch application and be approved to continue conducting branch activities at the location of its former main office?
multi-turn questions: How do such relocations impact the day-to-day operations of the bank?
Is a state member bank that relocates its main office required to file a branch application and be approved to continue conducting branch activities at the location of its former main office?
samples.answer: No. A state member bank's main office is not considered a branch even if branch activities (receiving deposits, paying checks, or lending money) are conducted at the site. Nevertheless, when a state member bank relocates its main office from a location where it already conducts branch activities, no regulatory purpose would be served by requiring the bank to submit an application to continue conducting branch activities at that location. Therefore, a state member bank that conducts branch activities at its main office may continue to conduct branch activities at the site following a main office relocation without filing a branch application. State member banks should contact the appropriate state banking regulator regarding applicable state laws with respect to the continuation of branch activities at the site of a former main office.

No regulatory purpose would be served by requiring a state member bank to submit an application to continue conducting branch activities at the site of its former main office
A state member bank that conducts branch activities at its main office may continue to do so at the site following a main office relocation without filing a branch application
State member banks should contact the appropriate state banking regulator regarding applicable state laws with respect to the continuation of branch activities at the site of a former main office.

samples.single-turn question: Under what conditions may a state member bank invest in a company that engages solely in activities permissible for the parent bank to engage in directly?
multi-turn questions: What are the current regulatory guidelines for state member banks when it comes to investing in external companies?
Under what conditions may a state member bank invest in a company that engages solely in activities permissible for the parent bank to engage in directly?
samples.answer: Under the Federal Reserve Act, state member banks are subject to the same limitations and conditions with respect to the purchasing, selling, underwriting, and holding of stock as apply to national banks. The Federal Reserve Act does not prohibit a state member bank from acquiring equity interests of a company that engages solely in activities permissible for the parent bank to engage in directly, provided that the bank "controls" the company. Such companies are called "operations subsidiaries." A state member bank controls a target company if the state member bank (i) directly or indirectly owns, controls, or holds with the power to vote 25 percent or more of the outstanding shares of any class of voting securities of the target company; (ii) exercises control in any manner over the election of a majority of the directors, trustees, or general partners of the company; or (iii) has the power to exercise, directly or indirectly, a controlling influence over the management or policies of the company. In determining control for these purposes, the Board considers the same factors it considers under the Bank Holding Company Act and Regulation Y. A member bank may only organize and operate operations subsidiaries at locations in the United States. A member bank must use authority under Regulation K to acquire foreign subsidiaries. Ownership interests in operations subsidiaries must comply with all state and other federal law.

Ownership interests in operations subsidiaries must comply with all state and other federal laws

samples.single-turn question: May a state member bank make a noncontrolling equity investment in a company that engages solely in activities permissible for the investing bank to engage in directly?
multi-turn questions: Are state member banks permitted to make equity investments in other companies?
For such equity investments, are noncontrolling stakes allowed under banking regulations?
May a state member bank make a noncontrolling equity investment in a company that engages solely in activities permissible for the investing bank to engage in directly?
samples.answer: In general, the Federal Reserve Act prohibits a state member bank from making a noncontrolling equity investment in a company, even if the company's activities are limited to those in which the investing bank could engage directly. In limited circumstances, Board staff would not recommend that the Board take an enforcement action against a bank for violation of the Federal Reserve Act with respect to a noncontrolling equity investment in another company. These circumstances include where (i) the company's activities are limited to those that are permissible for the bank; (ii) the bank has the ability to withdraw from or terminate the investment at any time; and (iii) the structure of the investment limits the bank's exposure, as a legal and accounting matter, to liability resulting from the actions of the company's other investors. State member banks may consult with Federal Reserve staff regarding whether a proposed noncontrolling equity investment would be prohibited under the Federal Reserve Act. Equity investments must comply with all state and other federal law.
must_have: In general, the Federal Reserve Act prohibits a state member bank from making a noncontrolling equity investment in a company, even if the company's activities are limited to those in which the investing bank could engage directly

Board staff would not recommend that the Board take an enforcement action against a bank for violation of the Federal Reserve Act with respect to a noncontrolling equity investment in another company under certain circumstances
One circumstance under which the Board staff would not recommend enforcement action is where the company's activities are limited to those that are permissible for the bank
Another circumstance under which the Board staff would not recommend enforcement action is where the bank has the ability to withdraw from or terminate the investment at any time

A further circumstance under which the Board staff would not recommend enforcement action is where the structure of the investment limits the bank's exposure, as a legal and accounting matter, to liability resulting from the actions of the company's other investors
State member banks may consult with Federal Reserve staff regarding whether a proposed noncontrolling equity investment would be prohibited under the Federal Reserve Act
Equity investments must comply with all state laws
Equity investments must comply with all other federal laws besides the Federal Reserve Act

samples.single-turn question: Does section 9(20) of the Federal Reserve Act prohibit a state member bank from acquiring equity securities solely for the purpose of hedging exposures arising from equity derivative transactions that the bank lawfully enters into with third parties?
multi-turn questions: Does section 9(20) of the Federal Reserve Act prohibit state member banks from acquiring equity securities for hedging purposes?

Does section 9(20) of the Federal Reserve Act prohibit a state member bank from acquiring equity securities solely for the purpose of hedging exposures arising from equity derivative transactions that the bank lawfully enters into with third parties?
samples.answer: Section 9(20) of the Federal Reserve Act does not prohibit a state member bank from purchasing equity securities to hedge the risks arising from equity derivative transactions lawfully entered into by the bank with an unaffiliated third party, provided that (i) such purchases are made in accordance with the same conditions and restrictions applicable to national banks, and (ii) the state member bank receives the approval of the Director of the Division of Supervision and Regulation before acquiring any equity security for hedging purposes. 12 U.S.C. § 335. In approving a state member bank to acquire equity securities for hedging purposes in 2007, the Board relied on commitments by the bank that it (i) would conduct its equity hedging activities in accordance with the conditions and restrictions applicable to the equity hedging activities of national banks, (ii) would not acquire equity securities for speculative or investment purposes, and (iii) would not acquire more than 5 percent of any class of equity securities of any issuer in connection with the bank's equity hedging activities. Consistent with the prohibition under federal law on a state member bank's engaging in underwriting and dealing in any equity security, the bank also committed not to hold itself out to the public as being willing to purchase or sell any equity security or act as a market-maker in any security by continuously quoting "bid" and "ask" prices for the security.

Such purchases must be made in accordance with the same conditions and restrictions applicable to national banks

The bank committed to conducting its equity hedging activities in accordance with the conditions and restrictions applicable to national banks

Consistent with federal law, the bank committed not to engage in underwriting and dealing in any equity security

samples.single-turn question: May a state member bank make a public welfare investment without prior approval in a project that is eligible to receive tax credits under the Department of Treasury's New Markets Tax Credit (NMTC) program?
multi-turn questions: What regulatory conditions apply when state member banks engage in NMTC-related public welfare investments?

May a state member bank make a public welfare investment without prior approval in a project that is eligible to receive tax credits under the Department of Treasury's New Markets Tax Credit (NMTC) program?
samples.answer: A NMTC-eligible investment, directly or indirectly, in an entity that is a "qualified community development entity" as defined in section 45D(c)(l) of the Internal Revenue Code (26 U.S.C. § 45D(c)(1)) is "designed primarily to promote the public welfare" within the meaning of section 9(23) of the Federal Reserve Act (12 U.S.C. § 338a). Accordingly, state member banks are authorized to make investments qualifying for the NMTC program under section 9(23) of the Federal Reserve Act, and may also be eligible for the Regulation H post-notice procedure, as long as those investments comply with all other applicable statutory and regulatory criteria.
must_have: A NMTC-eligible investment is designed primarily to promote the public welfare within the meaning of section 9(23) of the Federal Reserve Act (12 U.S.C. § 338a)

samples.single-turn question: May a state member bank make a public welfare investment without prior approval in a project that is not located in a low- and moderate-income area (LMI area), but that is located in an elevated poverty rate area?
multi-turn questions: What qualifies as a public welfare investment by a state member bank?
Is prior approval generally required for state member banks to make investments in certain areas?

May a state member bank make a public welfare investment without prior approval in a project that is not located in a low- and moderate-income area (LMI area), but that is located in an elevated poverty rate area?
samples.answer: State member banks may make certain investments in "elevated poverty areas" without prior Board approval when the investments are "designed primarily to promote the public welfare" within the meaning of section 9(23) of the Federal Reserve Act. 12 U.S.C. § 338a. "Elevated poverty areas" are areas within a census tract (or a group of contiguous census tracts) where 20 percent or more of the population lives below the federally defined poverty level. Thus, an investment in an entity that conducts activities in an elevated poverty area would be a permissible public welfare investment if an investment in an entity that conducts those same activities in an LMI area would be a permissible public welfare investment. As a result, state member banks are authorized to make investments in such entities under section 9(23) of the Federal Reserve Act, and may also be eligible for the Regulation H post-notice procedure, as long as those investments comply with all other applicable statutory and regulatory criteria.
must_have: State member banks may make certain investments in "elevated poverty areas" without prior Board approval
Investments must be designed primarily to promote the public welfare within the meaning of section 9(23) of the Federal Reserve Act

An investment in an entity conducting activities in an elevated poverty area would be a permissible public welfare investment if the same activities conducted in an LMI area would also be permissible
State member banks are authorized to make investments in such entities under section 9(23) of the Federal Reserve Act
Such investments may also be eligible for the Regulation H post-notice procedure
Investments must comply with all other applicable statutory and regulatory criteria to be permissible

samples.single-turn question: Can a state member bank make a public welfare investment in a housing project that includes multiple residential buildings?
multi-turn questions: How have the roles of state member banks evolved over time, especially in terms of community investment?
What current practices or guidelines do state member banks follow when considering public welfare investments?
Can a state member bank make a public welfare investment in a housing project that includes multiple residential buildings?
samples.answer: Section 9(23) of the Federal Reserve Act (12 U.S.C. § 338a) permits a state member bank to make public welfare investments if they are designed primarily to promote the public welfare, including the welfare of low- and moderate-income (LMI) communities or families. Regulation H permits a state member bank to make public welfare investments for the purpose of investing in, developing, rehabilitating, managing, selling, or renting residential property, provided that a majority of the units will be occupied by LMI persons (12 CFR 208.22(b)(1)(iv)(A)). In some cases, a state member bank may seek to make such an investment in a single housing project consisting of multiple buildings. For that investment to be considered a single investment, the buildings must be 'contiguous '. Contiguous means the buildings must be physically adjacent to one another (e.g., the property boundaries of each building must be connected and not separated by another property or space not associated with the project), or otherwise physically connected to one another by means of a dedicated underground, ground-level, or above-ground path such that residents of the buildings can traverse between the buildings in an uninterrupted manner. Buildings that are separated by other structures, properties, spaces, or public roads would not be considered contiguous, even if they are accessible via public sidewalks. In cases where contiguity is unclear, state member banks are encouraged to consult with Federal Reserve staff.
must_have: Section 9(23) of the Federal Reserve Act permits a state member bank to make public welfare investments if they are designed primarily to promote the public welfare
Public welfare investments may include the welfare of low- and moderate-income (LMI) communities or families
Regulation H allows a state member bank to invest in residential property for the purpose of promoting public welfare, provided a majority of the units will be occupied by LMI persons
A state member bank may make a public welfare investment in a single housing project consisting of multiple buildings, provided the buildings are considered contiguous
Buildings are considered contiguous if they are physically adjacent to one another or connected by a dedicated path allowing residents to move between buildings without interruption
Buildings separated by other structures, properties, spaces, or public roads are not considere contiguous, even if accessible via public sidewalks
State member banks are encouraged to consult with Federal Reserve staff in cases where contiguity is unclear

samples.single-turn question: When a state member bank makes a public welfare investment through a subsidiary and the investment is funded by (1) the bank's equity investment and (2) a nonrecourse loan from an unaffiliated party to the subsidiary for which neither the bank nor its subsidiaries or affiliates are liable for any unpaid amounts (a "leverage loan"), must the portion of the investment attributable to the leverage loan be included in the bank's public welfare investment amount, which is used to determine compliance with the aggregate public welfare investment limits under section 9(23) of the Federal Reserve Act, 12 U.S.C. § 338a, and section 208.22 of the Board's Regulation H?
multi-turn questions: Can you explain what a nonrecourse loan is and when it might be used by a bank's subsidiary?

When a state member bank makes a public welfare investment through a subsidiary and the investment is funded by (1) the bank's equity investment and (2) a nonrecourse loan from an unaffiliated party to the subsidiary for which neither the bank nor its subsidiaries or affiliates are liable for any unpaid amounts (a "leverage loan"), must the portion of the investment attributable to the leverage loan be included in the bank's public welfare investment amount, which is used to determine compliance with the aggregate public welfare investment limits under section 9(23) of the Federal Reserve Act, 12 U.S.C. § 338a, and section 208.22 of the Board's Regulation H?
samples.answer: Whether the amount attributable to the leverage loan is included in the state member bank's public welfare investment amount, which is used to determine compliance with the aggregate public welfare investment limits, depends on the structure and terms of the investment. State member banks may structure public welfare investments through a consolidated subsidiary or an unconsolidated entity. The subsidiary or entity receives the leverage loan and combines it with the equity investment to fund one or more public welfare investments. In an unconsolidated investment structure, only the bank's equity investment is reflected on the bank's balance sheet. Accordingly, the amount of the leverage loan is not an exposure of the bank, either from an economic (because the third-party lender has no recourse to the bank) or accounting perspective. Therefore, in this situation, the bank does not need to include the amount of the investment attributable to the leverage loan in its public welfare investment amount. In a consolidated investment structure, although the third-party lender has no recourse to the bank if the leverage loan is not repaid, the entire investment made by the subsidiary, using the proceeds from both the equity investment and the leverage loan, is reflected as an asset on the bank's balance sheet (and the leverage loan is reflected as a liability). Accordingly, as a general rule, the entire amount of the investment made by the subsidiary is treated as a public welfare investment made by the bank. However, under these circumstances, a state member bank may exclude from its public welfare investment amount the amount attributable to the leverage loan if the investment is eligible for New Markets Tax Credits (NMTCs), 26 U.S.C. § 45D, or Low-Income Housing Tax Credits (LIHTCs), 26 U.S.C. § 42, a majority of the bank's equity return derives from such tax credits, and the bank's equity investment is written down as the tax credits are received. This approach to NMTC and LIHTC investments facilitates the ability of a state member bank to make these types of public welfare investments in a safe and sound manner without unnecessarily constraining the amount of capital that the bank may allocate to such investments within the aggregate public welfare investment limits. State member banks must continue to ensure that public welfare investments made pursuant to section 208.22(b) of Regulation H meet the applicable permissibility criteria, including that such investments do not expose the bank to liability beyond the amount of the investment. 12 CFR 208.22(b)(3). For purposes of determining the appropriate accounting treatment for public welfare investments and related investment structures, including whether an entity must be consolidated, state member banks should refer to the Call Report instructions and U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.

In a consolidated investment structure, the entire investment made by the subsidiary, using the proceeds from both the equity investment and the leverage loan, is reflected as an asset on the bank's balance sheet

samples.single-turn question: In what ways may a U.S. banking organization conduct operations abroad under Regulation K?
multi-turn questions: Can you explain the primary regulatory hurdles U.S. banks face when expanding internationally?
In what ways may a U.S. banking organization conduct operations abroad under Regulation K?
samples.answer: Operations abroad by U.S. bank holding companies and member banks must be conducted through certain forms prescribed in statute and regulation. In particular, investments by member banks in foreign subsidiaries must be made with the Board's consent (i) under section 25 of the Federal Reserve Act (12 U.S.C. § 601 et seq.) or (ii) through an Edge corporation subsidiary under section 25A of the Federal Reserve Act (12 U.S.C. § 611 et seq.). In addition, U.S. bank holding companies may acquire the shares of certain foreign subsidiaries under section 4(c)(13) of the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 (BHC Act). 12 U.S.C. § 1843(c)(13). Regulation K implements these statutory provisions and, as a result, U.S. bank holding companies and member banks conduct operations abroad pursuant to requirements under Regulation K. Separately, financial holding companies may engage in activities abroad under section 4(k) of the BHC Act. 12 U.S.C. § 1843(k). Direct investments by a member bank under Regulation K are limited to Edge and agreement corporations; foreign banks; holding companies for foreign banks; entities providing nominee, fiduciary, or incidental services to foreign branches; and certain subsidiaries of foreign branches with Board approval.

U.S. bank holding companies may acquire the shares of certain foreign subsidiaries under section 4(c)(13) of the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 (BHC Act), 12 U.S.C. § 1843(c)(13)

samples.single-turn question: What types of activities may an Edge or agreement corporation or foreign subsidiary of a U.S. banking organization conduct in the United States?
multi-turn questions: Could you explain what constitutes a foreign subsidiary of a U.S. banking organization?
For such foreign subsidiaries, are their operations subject to U.S. regulatory oversight when conducting activities?
Beyond foreign subsidiaries, what are Edge and agreement corporations, and do they similarly operate under U.S. regulations within the country?
What types of activities may an Edge or agreement corporation or foreign subsidiary of a U.S. banking organization conduct in the United States?
samples.answer: An Edge or agreement corporation or foreign subsidiary of a U.S. banking organization may conduct activities in the United States that are incidental to its international or foreign business. Under the sixth paragraph of section 25A of the Federal Reserve Act (12 U.S.C. § 615(c)), an Edge corporation may, with the prior consent of the Board, purchase and hold stock of a corporation that is "not engaged in the general business of buying or selling goods, wares, merchandise or commodities in the United States, and not transacting any business in the United States except such as in the judgment of the Board . . . may be incidental to its international or foreign business." Similarly, under the eighth paragraph of the same section (12 U.S.C. § 616), an Edge corporation may not "carry on any part of its business in the United States except such as in the judgment of the Board . . . may be incidental to its international or foreign business." Pursuant to the third paragraph of section 25 of the Federal Reserve Act (12 U.S.C. § 601) and paragraph 20 of section 9 of the Federal Reserve Act (12 U.S.C. § 335), a member bank may acquire and hold, directly or indirectly, stock or other evidences of ownership in a foreign bank as long as such foreign bank is "not engaged, directly or indirectly, in any activity in the United States except as, in the judgment of the Board . . . shall be incidental to the international or foreign business of such foreign bank." Finally, section 4(c)(13) of the BHC Act exempts from the nonbanking prohibitions of section 4 of the BHC Act "shares of, or activities conducted by, any company which does no business in the United States except as an incident to its international or foreign business." 12 U.S.C. § 1843(c)(13). As the Board has indicated, the slight wording differences between the quoted portions of the above statutes were not intended by Congress to bear any meaningful significance. Accordingly, the Board has interpreted these provisions in the past as being synonymous. The scope of activities that are considered incidental to international or foreign business are set forth in Regulation K. 12 CFR 211.6.

An Edge corporation must obtain prior Board consent before purchasing such stock.
Under section 25A(8) of the Federal Reserve Act, an Edge corporation may not conduct business in the U.S. unless it is incidental to international or foreign business as judged by the Board

Under section 25(3) of the Federal Reserve Act, a member bank may acquire stock or ownership in a foreign bank if that bank does no business in the U.S. except as incidental to international or foreign business
Paragraph 20 of section 9 of the Federal Reserve Act permits similar ownership with the same condition

Section 4(c)(13) of the BHC Act exempts certain foreign subsidiaries from the general prohibition on owning commercial entities if their U.S. activities are incidental to international or foreign business
The Board has interpreted the quoted provisions of section 25 and section 4(c)(13) as synonymous in effect
Congress did not intend for the slight wording differences between these statutes to have substantive legal consequences
Regulation K (12 CFR 211.6) defines the scope of permissible activities that are incidental to international or foreign business.

samples.single-turn question: Are certain Islamic finance arrangements permissible under Regulation K?
multi-turn questions: How does Regulation K generally affect the operations of banks engaging in international activities?
What specific types of international banking products or services fall under Regulation K's regulatory scope?
Does Regulation K accommodate non-traditional banking models in its framework?
Are certain Islamic finance arrangements permissible under Regulation K?
samples.answer: Engaging in purchase or repurchase arrangements involving goods that are the functional equivalent of extensions of credit is an activity that is permissible as usual in connection with the transaction of the business of banking or other financial operations and is consistent with the supervisory purposes of the Federal Reserve Act, provided that (i) the goods are acquired with an irrevocable commitment from the customer to purchase or repurchase the goods involved and (ii) there is an irrevocable waiver of any customer recourse to the seller of the goods. Conducting this activity, subject to these conditions, would be permissible in countries where this activity is usual in connection with the business of banking.

multi-turn questions: How have the regulations for foreign banking organizations operating in the United States evolved over the past decade?
What are the current regulatory requirements for foreign banks engaging in financial activities within the U.S.?
What is the scope of permissible securities underwriting activities of foreign banking organizations in the United States?
samples.answer: A foreign banking organization that is subject to the BHC Act may engage in securities underwriting activities in the United States only if it has been authorized under section 4 of the BHC Act. 12 U.S.C. § 1843. Underwriting of securities to be distributed in the United States is an activity conducted in the United States, regardless of the location at which the underwriting risk is assumed and the underwriting fees are booked. Consequently, any foreign banking organization that wishes to engage in such activity must either be a financial holding company or have authority to engage in underwriting activity under section 4(c)(8) of the BHC Act (so-called "section 20 authority"). 12 U.S.C. § 1843(c)(8).
must_have: A foreign banking organization subject to the BHC Act may engage in securities underwriting activities in the United States only if authorized under section 4 of the BHC Act
Underwriting of securities to be distributed in the United States is considered an activity conducted in the United States
The location at which the underwriting risk is assumed does not affect whether the activity is considered conducted in the United States
The location at which the underwriting fees are booked does not affect whether the activity is considered conducted in the United States
Any foreign banking organization wishing to engage in securities underwriting activities in the United States must either be a financial holding company

Any foreign banking organization wishing to engage in securities underwriting activities in the United States must have authority to engage in underwriting activity under section 4(c)(8) of the BHC Act
Foreign banking organizations engaging in securities underwriting activities in the United States must have "section 20 authority" under 12 U.S.C. § 1843(c)(8).

samples.single-turn question: Is Board approval required for the conversion of (i) a federally licensed agency to a state-licensed agency or (ii) a state-licensed agency to a federally licensed agency?
multi-turn questions: What specific regulatory or internal approvals are typically required when converting a financial institution from a federal to a state license, or vice versa?
Is Board approval required for the conversion of (i) a federally licensed agency to a state-licensed agency or (ii) a state-licensed agency to a federally licensed agency?
samples.answer: No. Board approval under Regulation K is not required for the conversion of an agency from a federal agency to a state agency, or from a state agency to a federal agency. These conversions are not a change in the status of an office and are not, consequently, an establishment of an office for the purposes of Regulation K.
must_have: Board approval under Regulation K is not required for the conversion of a federally licensed agency to a state-licensed agency
Board approval under Regulation K is not required for the conversion of a state-licensed agency to a federally licensed agency
The conversion of an agency from a federal agency to a state agency is not considered a change in the status of an office
The conversion of an agency from a state agency to a federal agency is not considered a change in the status of an office
These conversions are not considered an establishment of an office for the purposes of Regulation K.

samples.single-turn question: When are depository organizations considered "affiliated" through common ownership and therefore not subject to the Interlocks Act?
multi-turn questions: How does the Interlocks Act typically apply to depository organizations?
Can you give specific examples of how the Interlocks Act has been enforced in real-world scenarios involving depository organizations?
What circumstances might exempt a depository organization from the Interlocks Act's restrictions?
When are depository organizations considered "affiliated" through common ownership and therefore not subject to the Interlocks Act?
samples.answer: Generally, the Interlocks Rule defines "affiliate" to have the meaning given in section 202 of the Interlocks Act. 12 CFR 212.2(a), 238.92(a); see 12 U.S.C. § 3201(3). Under that definition, two companies will generally be affiliates if more than 25 percent of the voting stock of one company is beneficially owned in the aggregate by one or more persons who also beneficially own in the aggregate more than 25 percent of the voting stock of the other company. However, under the Interlocks Rule, an affiliate relationship between depository organizations does not exist if the Board determines, after giving the affected persons the opportunity to respond, that the asserted affiliation was established in order to avoid the prohibitions of the Interlocks Act and does not represent a true commonality of interest between the depository organizations. The Board may deny affiliate status in situations where a person (together with members of his or her immediate family, as part of a control group over two organizations) (i) owns a nominal percentage of shares in one organization; and (ii) owns a substantially larger percentage of shares in the other organization. What constitutes a nominal percentage will vary from case to case.
must_have: The Interlocks Rule defines "affiliate" according to section 202 of the Interlocks Act, as stated in 12 CFR 212.2(a), 238.92(a); see 12 U.S.C. § 3201(3)

Two companies are generally considered affiliates if more than 25 percent of the voting stock of one company is beneficially owned by one or more persons who also own more than 25 percent of the voting stock of the other company

An affiliate relationship between depository organizations does not exist if the Board determines that the asserted affiliation was established to avoid the prohibitions of the Interlocks Act and does not represent a true commonality of interest

The Board may deny affiliate status if a person (with family members as part of a control group over two organizations) owns a nominal percentage of shares in one organization and a substantially larger percentage of shares in the other organization
What constitutes a nominal percentage varies from case to case

samples.single-turn question: In cases where multiple depository organizations each have a controlling ownership interest in a joint venture, would the Interlocks Act prohibit an interlock between a parent depository organization investor and the subsidiary joint venture?
multi-turn questions: How does the Interlocks Act apply to management interlocks between a depository organization and a joint venture it controls?
What are the implications under the Act if multiple depository organizations each hold a controlling ownership interest in the same joint venture?

In cases where multiple depository organizations each have a controlling ownership interest in a joint venture, would the Interlocks Act prohibit an interlock between a parent depository organization investor and the subsidiary joint venture?
samples.answer: No. The joint venture would be an affiliate of each parent depository organization. As the Interlocks Act was not intended to prohibit interlocks between affiliates, interlocks between the joint venture and its parent depository organization investors would not be prohibited by the Interlocks Act or the Interlocks Rule.
must_have: The joint venture would be considered an affiliate of each parent depository organization
The Interlocks Act was not designed to prohibit interlocks between affiliates
Interlocks between the joint venture and its parent depository organization investors would not be prohibited by the Interlocks Act
Interlocks between the joint venture and its parent depository organization investors would not be prohibited by the Interlocks Rule

samples.single-turn question: Would a person's service as a management official of a foreign bank trigger an interlock for purposes of the Interlocks Act if the person also serves as a management official of an unaffiliated U.S. depository organization?
multi-turn questions: How does the Act apply if one of those institutions is a foreign bank and the other is a U.S. depository organization?

Would a person's service as a management official of a foreign bank trigger an interlock for purposes of the Interlocks Act if the person also serves as a management official of an unaffiliated U.S. depository organization?
samples.answer: A management official's service at a foreign bank and an unaffiliated U.S. depository organization would not trigger an interlock for purposes of the Interlocks Act if the management official's service at the foreign bank relates principally to the foreign bank's business outside the United States. The Interlocks Act would apply, however, to a management official's service at a U.S. branch of a foreign bank and an unaffiliated U.S. bank holding company.
must_have: Service as a management official at a foreign bank and an unaffiliated U.S. depository organization would not trigger an interlock under the Interlocks Act if the service at the foreign bank is mainly related to its business outside the U.S.
The Interlocks Act would apply to a management official's service at a U.S. branch of a foreign bank and an unaffiliated U.S. bank holding company

samples.single-turn question: Is an interlock between a depository institution and a trust company subject to the prohibitions of the Interlocks Act and the Interlocks Rule?
multi-turn questions: What are the main purposes of the Interlocks Act and the Interlocks Rule?
Is an interlock between a depository institution and a trust company subject to the prohibitions of the Interlocks Act and the Interlocks Rule?
samples.answer: The prohibitions in the Interlocks Act apply to management officials of depository institutions or depository holding companies, and the statute defines depository institution to include, among other things, a trust company. 12 U.S.C. § 3201(1). Thus, generally, an interlock between a depository institution and a trust company would be subject to the prohibitions of the Interlocks Act and the Interlocks Rule. However, the Board previously has determined that trust companies that (i) do not have the power to accept deposits (other than in a fiduciary capacity) or to make personal or commercial loans and (ii) engage primarily in payments-, clearing-, and settlement-related activities are not depository institutions as contemplated by the Interlocks Act and the Interlocks Rule, and, therefore, are not subject to its prohibitions.
must_have: The prohibitions in the Interlocks Act apply to management officials of depository institutions or depository holding companies
The Interlocks Act defines depository institution to include a trust company
Generally, an interlock between a depository institution and a trust company would be subject to the prohibitions of the Interlocks Act and the Interlocks Rule

Trust companies that do not have the power to accept deposits (other than in a fiduciary capacity) or to make personal or commercial loans are not considered depository institutions under the Interlocks Act and the Interlocks Rule
Trust companies that engage primarily in payments-, clearing-, and settlement-related activities are not considered depository institutions under the Interlocks Act and the Interlocks Rule

Therefore, trust companies meeting the criteria of not having the power to accept deposits (other than in a fiduciary capacity) or to make personal or commercial loans and engaging primarily in payments-, clearing-, and settlement-related activities are not subject to the prohibitions of the Interlocks Act and the Interlocks Rule

samples.single-turn question: Under what circumstances would the Board find that a person is a "representative or nominee" of another person for purposes of the Interlocks Act and the Interlocks Rule?
multi-turn questions: What regulatory frameworks typically address interlocks between financial institutions?
Can you explain the key provisions of the Interlocks Act and the Interlocks Rule?
How do these regulations define the concept of a 'representative or nominee'?
What conditions generally determine if someone qualifies as a representative or nominee under such guidelines?
Under what circumstances would the Board find that a person is a "representative or nominee" of another person for purposes of the Interlocks Act and the Interlocks Rule?
samples.answer: For purposes of the Interlocks Rule, "representative or nominee" means a natural person who serves as a management official and has an obligation to act on behalf of another person with respect to management responsibilities. The Board will find that a person has an obligation to act on behalf of another person only if the first person has an agreement, express or implied, to act on behalf of the second person with respect to management responsibilities. The Board will determine, after giving the affected persons an opportunity to respond, whether a person is a representative or nominee of another person. 12 CFR 212.2(n); 12 CFR 238.92(n). In making such a determination, the Board may consider family, employment, or agency relationships between two persons as evidence of an express or implied obligation of one person to carry out management functions on the other person's behalf. Similarly, the ability of a person to elect a director and the exercise of that ability may be evidence of the elected official's express or implied obligation to the elector. However, neither a relationship nor the election of a director will in itself create an express or implied obligation. Whether or not such an obligation exists will be determined case by case, upon consideration of all relevant facts.
must_have: "Representative or nominee" under the Interlocks Rule means a natural person who serves as a management official and has an obligation to act on behalf of another person regarding management responsibilities
The Board will find a person has an obligation to act on behalf of another person only if there is an agreement, either express or implied, to do so
The Board will give affected persons an opportunity to respond before determining if someone is a representative or nominee of another person
The Board may consider family relationships as evidence of an express or implied obligation of one person to carry out management functions on another person's behalf
The Board may consider employment relationships as evidence of an express or implied obligation of one person to carry out management functions on another person's behalf
The Board may consider agency relationships as evidence of an express or implied obligation of one person to carry out management functions on another person's behalf
The ability of a person to elect a director and the exercise of that ability may be evidence of the elected official's express or implied obligation to the elector
Neither a relationship nor the election of a director alone will create an express or implied obligation
Whether an express or implied obligation exists will be determined on a case-by-case basis considering all relevant facts

samples.single-turn question: What is the time limit on an exception for interlocking service by a management official of a depository organization that is in danger of closing?
multi-turn questions: Regarding the financial stabilization measures for troubled depository institutions, are there any regulatory exceptions permitted for management officials?
What is the time limit on an exception for interlocking service by a management official of a depository organization that is in danger of closing?
samples.answer: The Interlocks Act and the Interlocks Rule provide a five-year exception for interlocking service where a depository organization that is closed or is in danger of closing is acquired by another depository organization. This exception also applies to bridge banks created by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to acquire and assume the deposits and liabilities of a failed bank. However, under the general exemption provisions of the Interlocks Rule, the Board may permit indefinitely an interlock that otherwise would be prohibited by the Interlocks Act if the Board determines that the interlock would not result in a monopoly or in a substantial lessening of competition and would not present safety and soundness concerns. The Interlocks Rule also provides that, in reviewing a request for an exemption, the Board will apply a rebuttable presumption that an interlock will not result in a monopoly or in a substantial lessening of competition if the depository organization seeking to add the management official is deemed to be in troubled condition.
must_have: The Interlocks Act and the Interlocks Rule provide a five-year exception for interlocking service where a depository organization that is closed or in danger of closing is acquired by another depository organization
This five-year exception applies to bridge banks created by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to acquire and assume the deposits and liabilities of a failed bank

Under the general exemption provisions of the Interlocks Rule, the Board may permit indefinitely an interlock that would otherwise be prohibited by the Interlocks Act if the Board determines that the interlock would not result in a monopoly or in a substantial lessening of competition and would not present safety and soundness concerns

In reviewing a request for an exemption, the Board will apply a rebuttable presumption that an interlock will not result in a monopoly or in a substantial lessening of competition if the depository organization seeking to add the management official is deemed to be in a troubled condition as defined in 12 CFR 225.71

samples.single-turn question: Are all management officials of a diversified savings and loan holding company subject to the prohibitions in the Interlocks Act and the Interlocks Rule?
multi-turn questions: For such companies, do the prohibitions in the Interlocks Act and Interlocks Rule extend to their management officials?
Are all management officials of a diversified savings and loan holding company subject to the prohibitions in the Interlocks Act and the Interlocks Rule?
samples.answer: All management officials of a savings and loan holding company (including a diversified savings and loan holding company) are generally subject to the prohibitions of the Interlocks Act; however, the Interlocks Act provides that a director of a diversified savings and loan holding company may serve as a director of an unaffiliated depository organization if (i) both the diversified savings and loan holding company and the unaffiliated depository organization notify their appropriate federal depository institution regulatory agencies at least 60 days before the dual service is proposed to begin; and (ii) with respect to each notification, the appropriate regulatory agency does not disapprove the dual service before the end of the 60-day period. This exception is not available to nondirector management officials. A management official of a diversified savings and loan holding company also may apply for a regulatory exemption.
must_have: All management officials of a savings and loan holding company, including a diversified savings and loan holding company, are generally subject to the prohibitions of the Interlocks Act
A director of a diversified savings and loan holding company may serve as a director of an unaffiliated depository organization under certain conditions

One condition for a director of a diversified savings and loan holding company to serve as a director of an unaffiliated depository organization is that both organizations must notify their appropriate federal depository institution regulatory agencies at least 60 days before the dual service is proposed to begin

Another condition for a director of a diversified savings and loan holding company to serve as a director of an unaffiliated depository organization is that the appropriate regulatory agency does not disapprove the dual service before the end of the 60-day period

This exception allowing a director of a diversified savings and loan holding company to serve as a director of an unaffiliated depository organization is not available to nondirector management officials
A management official of a diversified savings and loan holding company may apply for a regulatory exemption from the prohibitions of the Interlocks Act
The Interlocks Rule does not provide additional exceptions beyond those specified in the Interlocks Act for management officials of diversified savings and loan holding companies

samples.single-turn question: Could an estate or trust that owns or controls voting securities of a member bank be considered an insider of the member bank?
multi-turn questions: Could a diversified savings and loan holding company be considered an insider of a member bank based on its ownership or control of voting securities?
Could an estate or trust that owns or controls voting securities of a member bank be considered an insider of the member bank?
samples.answer: Yes. If an estate or trust, directly or indirectly, or acting in concert with one or more persons owns, controls, or has the power to vote more than 10 percent of any class of voting securities of a member bank, the estate or trust is a principal shareholder, and therefore an insider, of the member bank. Any loan made by a member bank to such an estate or trust, or any company controlled by the estate or trust, would be an extension of credit subject to Regulation O.
must_have: An estate or trust owning more than 10 percent of any class of voting securities of a member bank is considered a principal shareholder of the member bank
An estate or trust controlling more than 10 percent of any class of voting securities of a member bank is considered a principal shareholder of the member bank
An estate or trust having the power to vote more than 10 percent of any class of voting securities of a member bank is considered a principal shareholder of the member bank

An estate or trust acting in concert with one or more persons to own, control, or have the power to vote more than 10 percent of any class of voting securities of a member bank is considered a principal shareholder of the member bank
A principal shareholder of a member bank is considered an insider of the member bank
Any loan made by a member bank to an estate or trust that is a principal shareholder would be an extension of credit subject to Regulation O
Any loan made by a member bank to a company controlled by an estate or trust that is a principal shareholder would be an extension of credit subject to Regulation O

samples.single-turn question: Is the executor of an estate that owns more than 10 percent of a member bank a principal shareholder of the member bank?
multi-turn questions: What defines someone as a principal shareholder of a member bank?
Is there a specific ownership threshold that triggers principal shareholder status?
Does meeting that ownership percentage automatically classify someone as a principal shareholder?
How does this apply if the shares are held by an estate, not an individual?
Is the executor of an estate that owns more than 10 percent of a member bank a principal shareholder of the member bank?
samples.answer: Yes. A principal shareholder of a member bank is any person that directly or indirectly, or acting through or in concert with one or more persons, owns, controls, or has the power to vote more than 10 percent of any class of voting securities of the member bank. Shares of a member bank held by an estate are controlled indirectly by the executor of the estate. Accordingly, if an estate owns more than 10 percent of a class of voting securities of a member bank, the estate's executor has the power indirectly to control such shares and is thus a principal shareholder of the member bank.
must_have: A principal shareholder of a member bank is defined as any person owning, controlling, or having the power to vote more than 10 percent of any class of voting securities of the member bank
Shares of a member bank held by an estate are controlled indirectly by the executor of the estate
If an estate owns more than 10 percent of a class of voting securities of a member bank, the executor of the estate has the power to indirectly control such shares
The executor of an estate that owns more than 10 percent of a class of voting securities of a member bank is considered a principal shareholder of the member bank

samples.single-turn question: Would a guarantee by an insider for an extension of credit by a member bank to a third party be treated as an extension of credit to the insider?
multi-turn questions: Does the banking regulation treat insider guarantees differently than direct loans to insiders?
Would a guarantee by an insider for an extension of credit by a member bank to a third party be treated as an extension of credit to the insider?
samples.answer: Yes. The definition of "extension of credit" in section 215.3(a)(4) of Regulation O includes any evidence of indebtedness upon which an insider may be liable as guarantor. 12 CFR 215.3(a)(4). The amount of such an extension of credit to the insider equals the amount of the indebtedness for which the insider has provided a guarantee.
must_have: An insider's guarantee for an extension of credit by a member bank to a third party is treated as an extension of credit to the insider
According to section 215.3(a)(4) of Regulation O, any evidence of indebtedness upon which an insider may be liable as guarantor is included in the definition of "extension of credit"
The amount of the extension of credit to the insider is equal to the amount of the indebtedness for which the insider has provided a guarantee
This regulation is specified under 12 CFR 215.3(a)(4).

samples.single-turn question: Under the Federal Reserve's Regulation O, when is an extension of credit to an estate or trust treated as being made to a beneficiary?
multi-turn questions: Can you explain the purpose and scope of the Federal Reserve's Regulation O?
How does Regulation O handle credit extensions involving entities like estates or trusts?
What's the rationale behind including specific provisions for estate and trust credit extensions in Regulation O?
Under the Federal Reserve's Regulation O, when is an extension of credit to an estate or trust treated as being made to a beneficiary?
samples.answer: The tangible economic benefit rule in section 215.3(f) of Regulation O provides that an extension of credit to a third party will be treated as having been made to an insider to the extent that the proceeds are transferred to, or used for the tangible economic benefit of, an insider. Extensions of credit to an estate or trust inure to the benefit of the beneficiaries of the trust or estate. For purposes of Regulation O, an extension of credit to a trust or estate in which an insider has a present or contingent beneficial interest of 25 percent or more will be treated as made to the insider-beneficiary.
must_have: An extension of credit to a third party will be treated as having been made to an insider to the extent that the proceeds are transferred to, or used for the tangible economic benefit of, an insider according to the tangible economic benefit rule in section 215.3(f) of Regulation O
Extensions of credit to an estate or trust inure to the benefit of the beneficiaries of the trust or estate

For purposes of Regulation O, an extension of credit to a trust or estate in which an insider has a present or contingent beneficial interest of 25 percent or more will be treated as made to the insider-beneficiary

samples.single-turn question: May a member bank offer a discount on loan origination fees to an insider if the discount is not available to members of the public?
multi-turn questions: What regulatory requirements apply to banks when extending loans to their insiders?
Specifically, do these regulations permit variations in loan fees between insiders and the general public?
May a member bank offer a discount on loan origination fees to an insider if the discount is not available to members of the public?
samples.answer: No, with one exception, explained below. Regulation O prohibits a member bank from extending credit to an insider that is not made on substantially the same terms as, or is made without following credit underwriting procedures that are at least as stringent as, comparable transactions with persons that are non-insiders and not employees of the bank. 12 CFR 215.4(a)(1). This provision does not, however, prohibit a member bank from extending credit to an insider as part of a benefit or compensation program that (i) is widely available to employees of the member bank and (ii) does not give preference to any insider of the member bank over other employees of the member bank. 12 CFR 215.4(a)(2).
must_have: No, a member bank cannot offer a discount on loan origination fees to an insider if the discount is not available to members of the public
Regulation O prohibits a member bank from extending credit to an insider on terms that are not substantially the same as those offered to non-insiders and non-employees
Credit underwriting procedures for insiders must be at least as stringent as those for comparable transactions with non-insiders and non-employees
There is an exception to this rule if the discount is part of a benefit or compensation program
The exception applies if the benefit or compensation program is widely available to employees of the member bank
The exception also requires that the program does not give preference to any insider of the member bank over other employees of the member bank
This regulation is outlined in 12 CFR 215.4(a)(1) and 12 CFR 215.4(a)(2)

samples.single-turn question: Under the Federal Reserve's Regulation O, what types of properties and how many properties may qualify as a "residence" of an executive officer for purposes of the "residence" exception to the restrictions on extensions of credit to executive officers?
multi-turn questions: What are some of the common exceptions provided under Regulation O for loans to executive officers?

Under the Federal Reserve's Regulation O, what types of properties and how many properties may qualify as a "residence" of an executive officer for purposes of the "residence" exception to the restrictions on extensions of credit to executive officers?
samples.answer: The prohibition on extensions of credit to an executive officer does not apply to an extension of credit used to refinance, purchase, construct, maintain, or improve a residence of the executive officer. This exception is available only for one property of an executive officer, and only for a property used as a residence of the executive officer. The property must be a house, condominium, cooperative, mobile home, house trailer, houseboat, or other similar property that has sleeping, cooking, and toilet facilities. The exception may be used for a property that is not a primary residence so long as the executive officer uses the property as a residence and does not use this exception for any other property.

This exception under Federal Reserve's Regulation O is available only for one property of an executive officer
The property must be used as a residence of the executive officer to qualify for the exception under Federal Reserve's Regulation O
The property must be a house to qualify for the exception under Federal Reserve's Regulation O
The property must be a condominium to qualify for the exception under Federal Reserve's Regulation O
The property must be a cooperative to qualify for the exception under Federal Reserve's Regulation O

The property must have sleeping, cooking, and toilet facilities to qualify for the exception under Federal Reserve's Regulation O

samples.single-turn question: Has Regulation W been revised to reflect the amendments to sections 23A and 23B of the Federal Reserve Act (FRA) from the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Dodd-Frank Act)?
multi-turn questions: What is the core purpose of Regulation W and when was it first established?
How have the requirements and scope of Regulation W evolved since its initial implementation?
What current operational challenges do banks face due to Regulation W's provisions?
How did the Dodd-Frank Act specifically amend sections 23A and 23B of the Federal Reserve Act?
Has Regulation W been revised to reflect the amendments to sections 23A and 23B of the Federal Reserve Act (FRA) from the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Dodd-Frank Act)?
samples.answer: Regulation W has not yet been revised to reflect the amendments to sections 23A and 23B of the FRA from the Dodd-Frank Act. Nevertheless, the amendments made by the Dodd-Frank Act to sections 23A and 23B of the FRA became effective on July 21, 2011. Among other changes, the Dodd-Frank Act revised the process by which an insured depository institution (IDI) could be granted an exemption from the requirements of section 23A, generally authorizing the primary federal banking agency for the IDI to grant such requests by order, although the Board also is required to make certain findings before an exemption may be granted. Accordingly, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) may, by order, exempt a transaction of a national bank or federal savings association from the requirements of section 23A if (i) the Board and the OCC jointly find that granting the exemption would be in the public interest and consistent with the purposes of section 23A and (ii) the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) is notified of the finding and does not object, in writing, to the finding within 60 days based on a determination that the exemption presents an unacceptable risk to the Deposit Insurance Fund. The FDIC may, by order, exempt a transaction of a state nonmember bank and state savings association, and the Board may, by order, exempt a transaction of a state member bank, if, in all cases, (i) the FDIC and Board jointly find that granting the exemption would be in the public interest and consistent with the purposes of section 23A and (ii) the FDIC finds that the exemption does not present an unacceptable risk to the Deposit Insurance Fund. An IDI seeking an exemption from section 23A should contact its primary federal supervisor, the Board, and the FDIC.

The OCC can grant an exemption if the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) is notified of the finding and does not object, in writing, to the finding within 60 days based on a determination that the exemption presents an unacceptable risk to the Deposit Insurance Fund

The Board may, by order, exempt a transaction of a state member bank from the requirements of section 23A

samples.single-turn question: Where can I find Board interpretations and statements concerning Regulation W?
multi-turn questions: What significant changes or updates have happened to Regulation W in recent years?
Where can I find Board interpretations and statements concerning Regulation W?
samples.answer: In addition to the preamble to Regulation W (67 Fed. Reg. 76560 (December 12, 2002)), certain Board statements on sections 23A and 23B of the FRA can be found in Federal Register notices related to Regulation KK (85 Fed. Reg. 39754, 39764 (July 1, 2020)) and the Interagency Policy Statement on Income Tax Allocation in a Holding Company Structure (79 Fed. Reg. 35228 (June 19, 2014)). The Board also has published the approval letters for all Regulation W exemptions granted by the Board since 1996 on the Board's website. See here. The Federal Reserve Regulatory Service (FRRS) contains certain additional staff interpretations. A Board staff memo on the general application of sections 23A and 23B and Regulation W also is available on the Board's website.

samples.single-turn question: Would a merchant banking or insurance company investment portfolio company trigger the presumption of affiliation in section 223.2(a)(9)(i) of Regulation W if the holding company of the member bank controls 12 percent of the equity capital and voting stock of the portfolio company under the merchant banking or insurance company investment authority of section 4(k)(4)(H) or (I) of the Bank Holding Company Act (BHC Act), and 4 percent of the equity capital and voting stock of the portfolio company under section 4(c)(6) of the BHC Act?
multi-turn questions: What is the core purpose of Regulation W for bank holding companies?
How does the Bank Holding Company Act regulate investments in merchant banking and insurance companies?
What constitutes a 'presumption of affiliation' under section 223.2(a)(9)(i) of Regulation W?
How do investments under sections 4(k)(4)(H), 4(k)(4)(I), and 4(c)(6) of the BHC Act interact with Regulation W's affiliation rules?

Would a merchant banking or insurance company investment portfolio company trigger the presumption of affiliation in section 223.2(a)(9)(i) of Regulation W if the holding company of the member bank controls 12 percent of the equity capital and voting stock of the portfolio company under the merchant banking or insurance company investment authority of section 4(k)(4)(H) or (I) of the Bank Holding Company Act (BHC Act), and 4 percent of the equity capital and voting stock of the portfolio company under section 4(c)(6) of the BHC Act?
samples.answer: Yes, since a bank holding company may not own any shares of a company in reliance on section 4(c)(6) of the BHC Act if it owns or controls, in the aggregate under a combination of authorities, more than 5 percent of any class of voting securities of the company.
